awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:CDS&E:D3SC:Topology, Rare-event Simulation, and Machine Learning as Routes to Predicting Molecular Crystal Structures and Understanding Their Phase Behavior.
awd_abstract_narration:
Mark Tuckerman of New York University and Jerome Delhommelle of the University of North Dakota are supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry  to develop computational methods and software to study molecular crystals. Ordered arrays of molecules forming structures known as molecular crystals play an essential role in the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, electronics, and defense industries.  In many instances, a given chemical compound may have more than one  crystal structure, a phenomenon known as polymorphism.  A   crystal may also contain impurities, the most important among these being water.   Such structures are referred to as crystal hydrates. The ability of these materials to function in a desired manner may depend on which structure, pure or impure, they form.  If  a  well-engineered molecular crystal converts to  another form or if it absorbs impurities over time., its performance may be seriously degraded.  Such transformations can, for example, cause drugs to fail or insecticides to lose their potency. On the other hand, polymorphism and hydrate formation in molecular crystals are features that can be exploited to enhance the performance of these material.  Utilizing advances in high-performance computing and artificial intelligence, the theoretical molecular sciences are currently poised to drive new directions in molecular crystal engineering.  Computational approaches have the potential to highlight potential pitfalls associated with structural and compositional variability before expensive experiments are performed or large investments in manufacturing a particular material are made. With the aim of realizing this potential,  Professors Tuckerman and Delhommelle  propose to create new computational approaches and software components for rapidly predicting polymorphic structures in molecular crystals and understanding the transitions between structures.    Broad dissemination of these tools and their incorporation into the materials design and engineering processes will affect a reduction in time between concept and realization of crystal systems with desired optimal properties and will catalyze the creation of new course materials for enhancing STEM education. 

The basic properties of organic molecular materials in the solid state are often strongly influenced by the details of their crystal structures and the existence of polymorphs and/or impurities such as water. Experimental determination of these structures is costly and time-consuming, which places increased importance on the role of theory and computation and the leveraging of advances in high-performance computing machine learning methods. The aim of this project is to develop a suite of new methods and software tools for the prediction of organic molecular crystal structures, including multiple polymorphs, elucidation of the mechanisms and thermodynamics of polymorphic and solid-liquid phase transitions, and the mapping of favored locations for water molecules in stoichiometric and non-stoichiometric crystal hydrates. The proposed developments bring together techniques of topological analysis, machine learning, enhanced molecular dynamics, thermodynamics, and solvation theories. The main goals of the project are (1) to create a topological theory for crystal structure generation based on solely on molecular order parameters, thus bypassing the need to parameterize an intermolecular interaction model, (2) to develop new entropy- and path-based collective variables, aided by machine learning , for studying polymorphic transitions via state-of-the-art enhanced sampling techniques, and (3) to devise new theoretical and computational techniques for mapping the locations of water molecules in non-stoichiometric crystal hydrates. Broad dissemination of these tools and methods and their incorporation into crystal engineering pipelines could indicate fruitful directions in materials design, thus effecting a reduction in time between concept and realization of systems with desired properties and lead to the creation of new learning modules for graduate level courses in topics such as statistical mechanics, science of materials, and machine learning in the molecular sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organic molecular crystals constitute a class of materials of critical importance in numerous industries such as pharmaceuticals, organic electronics, agrochemicals, and energetic materials. In many cases, a given chemical compound may be able to crystallize into different structures, a phenomenon known as “polymorphism”; polymorphism is important in that the properties of these materials often depend on their structure, and different polymorphs often exhibit different properties.  In the world of pharmaceuticals, for example, some crystalline forms will be soluble in the stomach and, therefore, therapeutically active, while others may not be.  Consequently, our ability to predict crystal structures and polymorphs of organic molecules is a critical problem.

Despite the ubiquity of organic molecular crystal systems, our ability to predict molecular crystal structures starting only from a two-dimensional diagram of the constituent compound(s) remains a significant challenge.  Most structure-prediction protocols require a customized and system-specific model of the full set of interatomic interactions in the crystal.  Such models require substantial computational time, often weeks to months for a single prediction, and resources to develop and lead to a bias in the predictions of the crystal structures such that different models can yield different predictions.  It is, thus, clear that more efficient and direct approaches are needed.

Inspired by the work of the Swiss mathematician and crystallographer, Johann Jakob Burckhardt, who, in a paper he wrote in 1967, suggested that a pure mathematical approach to crystal structure prediction should be possible, we have developed such a mathematical framework that is capable of generating consistent and accurate predictions of molecular crystal structures in a matter of hours on a midrange laptop computer.  The mathematical rules were deduced by studying the structures of over 250,000 organic molecular crystal structures from the Cambridge Crystal Data Center, from which we found mathematical procedures for determining the orientation of molecules in the crystal, the parameters of the crystal lattice, itself, and the specific transformations for generating the entire crystal from the location of one of the constituent molecules.  We are calling our mathematical workflow, “Crystal Math”.  As the rules are applied, an initially large pool of possible structures becomes narrowed and refined until the experimentally realizable structures are all that remain. 

The accompanying graphic shows the application of the rules of Crystal Math to a familiar pharmaceutical, aspirin, which actually has three known polymorphs.  The two-dimensional scatter plot in the graphic shows the narrowing of the pool of possible structures through the three stages of the Crystal Math protocol on a plane that shows the amount of “empty” space or “free volume” in the crystal (molecular crystals prefer close packing and favor structures with low free volume) on the horizontal axis and a measure of the interatomic close contacts (which stands in for the aforementioned expensive energy calculations) on the vertical axis.  The three structures are also shown in the graphic.  The entire calculation required only six hours on an ordinary laptop.  The second graphic shows a much more complicated compound posed to us by a drug-development group at Pfizer.  This highly flexible molecule can be handled by Crystal Math using an intuitive approach of breaking the molecule down into small fragments (like breaking a complicated problem into smaller, easier problems), applying the rules to each fragment, and then keeping only those results that match for each fragment.  The graphic shows the molecule, the scatter plot, and the structure that results.  The entire calculation required only thirty hours on a standard laptop.

As this project continues to evolve, we will begin to develop generative artificial intelligence (AI) procedures for predicting key properties of these crystalline materials based only on the mathematical rules we have derived from the Cambridge database.  The third graphic illustrates how this will work for the prediction of a simple property, namely, the crystal density.  The model takes as an input a mathematical abstraction of the crystal known as a graph (just a set of points and lines connecting them in specific ways), which is understandable by AI such models.  Our ultimate goal is to teach the AI model to work with Crystal Math to predict properties such as solubility, for determining the performance of a pharmaceutical crystal, or ability to transport charge, important for the performance of organic electronic materials.
